question: I received a formal request for marriage today for Anne. From the Carey family.
answer: But that's wonderful.

question: I turned it down. And offered them Mary instead. Fnne's too good for William Carey. She can do (better than a merchant's son.
answer: You underestimate Mary.

question: Are you happy?
answer: Very.

question: You don't secretly wish you'd married someone grander? With a title?
answer: No. I want a husband who loves me. And who thinks it first thing every morning. And last thing at night.

question: Finally we can present George, and with luck, get him a position at court.
answer: These are difficult times. I have it on good authority that the Queen no longer bleeds - yet the matter of a male heir is still not resolved. a beat) It cannot be long before the King is forced to look outside the marriage.

question: What? And make a bastard King of England?
answer: A legitimized bastard. What choice does he have? Obviously, I've given it thought, and wondered which Howard girl I could put under his nose. Imagine the influence that would give us. To be blood family of the next King of England. Equally, imagine if another family were to achieve the same?

question: What about Anne? I realise as a `Boleyn' she is not officially a `Howard', but as your sister's daughter..
answer: But she's your eldest, Thomas. Your first born. And your favourite. Wouldn't you prefer her to have a nice, uncomplicated, respectable marriage? Like Mary?

question: o - the King himself is coming to Hever. I'm so happy for George.
answer: Yes. But Father took me aside. It seems he has ambitions for me, too.

question: What? What are you saying..?
answer: It's known the King has a wandering eye. Imagine...if he were to like me?

question: But...you could never be more than his mistress. And that's no substitute for a husband.
answer: But as the King's mistress the least I'd get after he finished with me would be an Earl. And if I fell pregnant? And gave him what his wife has failed to? a beat) Quite apart from the money, it'd be a Duke at least.

question: But what about your happiness? Your future?
answer: I could be a happy Duchess. Are you nervous?

question: A little.
answer: You'll tell me everything in the morning?

question: I promise.
answer: No details spared?

question: A pleasure.
answer: Here is the library.

question: Charming.
answer: And through here, the observatory..

question: Lovely.. What's that?
answer: falcon, your Grace.

question: I can see that. But what's it doing there? More to the point.. ..not just there, but in every corner in the house?
answer: I have no idea. Ask my father. a beat) Perhaps because falcons are vaguely associative with field sports - field sports with aristocracy - and in the absence of a genuine coat of arms.. ...a man with ambition will do the strangest things.

question: Or our navy? The finest in the world.
answer: It's true.

question: The universities in Spain and the philosophers in Germany may be strong, but are they really the equal of Oxford and Thomas More?
answer: Never!

question: I doubt there is a country that is fairer in Government, or better protected by nature from her enemies, whose people are happier or more prosperous..
answer: She's right, by God! She's right!

question: Good morning, Anne.
answer: Good morning, your Grace.

question: ho will you be riding with?
answer: On my own your Grace.

question: Your own..?
answer: They have invented a new saddle which allows ladies to ride on their own.

question: ut with no man to hold onto? How will you stay on the horse?
answer: Why? The same way you hold onto yours, your Grace.

question: We'll see. Let's away! Hah! Hah..! Then we must follow.
answer: Hah!

question: And who are you?
answer: Mary, your Grace. Anne's younger sister.

question: You've been here all week-end?
answer: Yes, your Grace.

question: Really? How could I have overlooked you?
answer: Next to Anne, it's easy to do.

question: Nonsense.
answer: Yes, your Grace. To William Carey.

question: Yes, your Grace.
answer: Then why haven't I seen you at court?

question: Because I have persuaded him to spend a year or two here first. We have a small manor and some land. Nothing much. But enough to start a family.
answer: A charmed life in the country? Away from it all?

question: Yes.
answer: Everything I would have wished for myself. But then my brother died. a beat) And duty called. You don't think he'll miss court? a beat) A young, ambitious man?

question: He says not, your Majesty. But, if he ever changed his mind, I would always support him.
answer: Well said. Thank you again, Lady Elizabeth. We'll take good care of your boy.. And Thomas.. You'll take care of that matter?

question: But what about our future? Here in the country?
answer: Put it out of your mind. From now on your home is at court.

question: William, please! Don't you understand what this means? They will separate us. Put me in different accommodation. Where the King can always...find me.
answer: Happily your husband understands the value of such an opportunity. For us all.

question: How could he DO this to me? My own father. a beat) What if we just refused?
answer: We would be cut off. He made that clear.

question: But would that be so bad? Position means nothing to me. Nor wealth. We could find somewhere. A small farm. Away from everything.
answer: You say that now - but when you're older? And our children are grown up? This won't last long. A year. Maybe two. And at the end of that - we'll we have everything we want. It's for our FUTURE.

question: Who? Really? But I was not expecting anyone. By my husband? Really? Well, then she must be some kind of gift. He must have seen in her some special talent that would please me. Tell me. What special talent is it that you have? with icy contempt) Apart from your obvious youth and beauty? oetry, perhaps?
answer: N-no..

question: Or dressmaking? Music! That's it! You compose? Or sing?
answer: ..I'm afraid not. Your Majesty.

question: Come, you're too modest. turns to a MUSICIAN) Signor Vasquez.
answer: No..really..I beg you, your Majesty.

question: I command you to SING!!! Bravo! A nightingale! Welcome at court!
answer: Mary Carey. Yes. I can't imagine. Should I mention you to him? Of course. Happily.

question: Mary Carey. Yes. I can't imagine. Should I mention you to him? Of course. Happily.
answer: Not noticed her? Jane Parker? Of course I have. How could I not? She looks like a goat.

question: Well, she likes you, and asked me to give you this..to remember her by.
answer: Ugh. Well say you haven't seen me. Or that you forgot.

question: And our sister? Any word?
answer: ANNE? You know she took being upstaged by you very badly.

question: Yes, I know.
answer: And no amount of interventions on my behalf would make her believe you hadn't done it intentionally.

question: But you KNOW I would never do anything like that.
answer: I know.

question: George? It's the middle of the night.
answer: t's Anne.

question: hat?
answer: he's married Henry Percy!

question: What?
answer: In secret. Without telling anyone!

question: Oh, no...!
answer: tailing off) You don't look pleased.

question: Why would I be pleased?
answer: It would make her the future Duchess of Northumberland. Our sister!

question: But they'll never allow it, don't you see? He's already precontracted to Mary Talbot, and if word of the consummation gets out her reputation will be ruined.. ...I have to tell Father. Before it's too late..
answer: What? Mary..! Wait! Come back!

question: Who knows about this?
answer: No one.

question: Then that is how it shall remain. Forever.
answer: But you cannot undo what has been done before God. And consummated too.

question: ANNE, wait..! What reason have I to be happy? Do I know you? Wait! Who ARE you? My name is Kindness.
answer: wonder, will you be kind to me?

question: What is it you desire?
answer: our love, fair Lady.

question: You demand a great deal.
answer: No more than I would give in return.

question: It is easy for a man to declare love from behind a mask. If your feelings were sincere, I would never reject you.
answer: But you do not know who I am? I could be ugly. Or poor.

question: o matter how you looked. Or who you were.
answer: Really? Then I shall hold you to your word. And unmask..!

question: Thank you, your Grace.
answer: `Henry', please. The first rule of this room, is to leave `Your Grace's' and `Your Majesty's' outside. Is there anything I can bring you?

question: No.
answer: Nothing to increase your comfort or well- being?

question: You might ask your servants to bring me some water.
answer: There. There ARE no servants.

question: So, this is it? This is where the King of England sleeps?
answer: And reads. And writes. And finds a few moments each day... ...for himself.

question: And yet you invite me here?
answer: Because I trust you.

question: You hardly know me.
answer: A man in my position develops an instinct. a beat) You would never lie, could never lie to me.

question: No.
answer: I also sense...that you might relish an opportunity to be yourself, too.

question: Yes.
answer: Well, here you only say what you like, do what you like.

question: Very well. I'd like an apple, please.. ..Henry. Now it's your turn.
answer: What?

question: To say something, or do something you couldn't outside.
answer: There are many things I cannot admit to in public. Sadness, for example. And loneliness.

question: But when you are loved as much as you are? How can you be lonely?
answer: Do you not know what it is to be lonely in a marriage?

question: My father..? a beat) Well, we'd better not keep him waiting.
answer: Well..? Did he have you?

question: Yes.
answer: More than once? You'd better get used to talking about it. Once you sleep with the king, it's not a private matter any more.

question: Yes. More than once.
answer: So he was satisfied?

question: I believe so, Uncle.
answer: ood. This is where our work begins. It's one thing to catch the king. Quite another to keep him. I want you to keep her spotless, hair washed every day. She must read all the latest books and be able to venture and defend an interesting opinion. She must know her music, must be energetic and entertaining - in company and in bed. That's how he likes his women. And if ever she's in any doubt as to how to conduct herself, or what to do next - she should simply watch the Queen. That woman kept him from straying for eleven years. And the effort almost killed her.

question: The biggest warship in the fleet. Thirty- two guns and two hundred feet long, and with your permission Thomas.. ..I'd like to name her after your daughter. The "Mary Boleyn".
answer: Majesty! I'm...I'm speechless..

question: onsense. She's an angel. It's the least she deserves. And if there's anything else I can do for YOU, my friend..as an expression of my gratitude..let me know.
answer: s it happens..there is one thing.

question: Name it.
answer: ur son, George. He's of an age now..

question: You want me to make him a match?
answer: Yes, your Majesty.

question: Do you have anyone in mind?
answer: There is one lady, Sir..

question: Go on..
answer: Who I fear is too high-born for us. And following the unfortunate matter between Anne and Henry Percy, I didn't want my children to overreach themselves again..

question: For God's sake, it's the wedding of our youngest child attended by the King of England and the greatest Lords in the Land. Would a smile be too much to ask?
answer: What's to smile about? I'm a mother with one child on his wedding day looking like he's been condemned to death. Another banished abroad, in disgrace. And a third whoring in public with an adulterer.

question: For the moment she's happy.
answer: But will she be happy when he leaves her? Because you know that's how it will end.

question: Only God knows how anything will end.
answer: God..? He turned his back on all this a long time ago.

question: You're in love with him, aren't you?
answer: illiam, you're drunk.

question: How is it? With him?
answer: He pleases me. Is that what you want to hear?

question: What does he do to you? Tell me. I want to know.. I know you look at me with contempt. But I had no choice. Your father insisted I stand aside. What was I expected to do?
answer: Say `no', husband. That was all you had to do.

question: Why?
answer: I suppose they felt three years of exile was punishment enough.

question: But the King visits me every day. There's no need for her. Or anyone else.
answer: They just want to protect you. Leave nothing to chance.

question: But in who's interests do they imagine Anne will act? Certainly not mine.
answer: Don't worry. She's had three years to forgive you. And she's not going to risk being sent away again. She'll do as she's told, I'm sure. Besides, the most important thing is.. The three of us will be together again.

question: What's the noise? I can hardly hear myself think! I'm only aware of one Boleyn girl and she is lying-in with a certain child in her belly!
answer: It's my elder daughter, Anne, your Majesty. She has returned to court.

question: What? That awful girl, Thomas? The one that almost killed me? You allowed her back?
answer: The time abroad has done her good, your Majesty. I'm certain you'd find her much improved.

question: Really..? Well, come on. Where are you, other Boleyn girl? Show your face. So? What is so amusing, Anne? Perhaps we might hear and judge for ourselves?
answer: I was just giving my thoughts on the new French King.

question: Which are..?
answer: That for someone with such great wealth, and power..he has surprisingly little authority as a man.

question: Hah!
answer: And is SO consumed by one particular rivalry he can barely think.

question: eally? And who is this rival?
answer: A neighbouring King, who's name one is forbidden to mention at court. Whose reputation haunts him in his thoughts and dreams. Whose armies and navy thwart his every endeavour. Whose physical and intellectual endowments are known far and wide. In order to restore his confidence, this French King spends a fortune on anything that glitters, on building of castles with large towers.. But these symbols of wealth and virility fail to convince. Talk among the ladies at court in France suggests..

question: What?
answer: That in this department too, the King has his shortcomings.

question: You should have seen the Seymours! Their faces! They must have thought that with you out of the way, they had a real opportunity with that pale-faced thing of theirs, Jane...
answer: Or HER, you mean.

question: What?
answer: 'm wary of any suggestion that Anne would serve anyone but herself. France can't have changed her THAT much.

question: n this occasion I am quite satisfied she was being loyal to you.
answer: Really?

question: She did what? Sent it back? What? Again?
answer: Your Majesty.

question: Your daughter. Where is she?
answer: Mary..?

question: Anne! Anne.. A
answer: Your Grace?

question: You received my gifts?
answer: Yes.

question: And? They did not please you?
answer: On the contrary, my Lord. They pleased me greatly.

question: Then why did you return them?
answer: ecause my sister lies in bed with your child. If you wish to please me, Sir, then send her the gifts you send me.

question: I have shown Mary enough kindness and generosity. It's you I want, Anne.
answer: beg you, my Lord, do not do this. What has changed so?

question: YOU. Don't you see? YOU have changed.
answer: But Mary is still the mother of your child. And even if she weren't..

question: How could I forget that you chose her above me when we first met? You liked her better.
answer: Not true..

question: Either way, I could never betray my own sister..
answer: You see! The same pain as mine! It proves you feel the same way!

question: Perhaps. But since it can never come to anything..
answer: Let me decide that. For now, you have given me hope.

question: Anne.. Anne, I love you..
answer: Your Grace, this is not the time..

question: I love you Anne. I cannot stop thinking about you. I cannot eat, I cannot sleep..
answer: But how could I ever TRUST you? When I have seen how you have betrayed first your wife. And now my sister.

question: I vow from this moment forth I will never lie with my wife, or speak to your sister again. I will do anything you ask..
answer: Then don't acknowledge the child.

question: How can you show your face in here?
answer: I understand you're angry - but be assured. I did nothing, except remind him of you.

question: Oh, spare me. You did this deliberately. As revenge. And now you have what you wanted you probably think justice has been done.
answer: Well, hasn't it?

question: Be careful, that's my advice. Learn from my experience. Because he'll only do to you what he has done to me.
answer: Never. I'll make sure he understands I'm a greater thing by far. That he can never have me until he makes me a far greater offer.

question: You'll never get Henry Percy back, if that's what you mean.
answer: That's not what I mean. And don't you ever mention his name to me again. I'll never forget how you betrayed me.

question: If that's what you think, fine. Tell yourself that.
answer: I did, sister. Every day for three years.

question: Have you christened the child?
answer: Henry.

question: I see. And is he to take my name? Or is he to be a Fitzroy or some other sign that he is a royal bast...
answer: He is to be Henry Carey.

question: Well, I have done what you asked. Will you give yourself to me, now?
answer: As what?

question: My one true mistress. To whom I am loyal above all others?
answer: But it's not true. You are loyal to the QUEEN above all others.

question: My wife? I barely see her.
answer: But she sits on a throne beside you. Accompanies you to every state function.

question: Still, she is your WIFE. And ever present. And I feel her eyes on me. And those of her spies. And look at us. Forever reduced to meeting in secret like this. Speaking in whispers. a beat) Hardly conducive to passion?
answer: Well, what would you have me do? Wolsey has agreed to draw up plans for the Queen to be sent to a nunnery. She will protest, of course. She won't go quietly, but she knows she has failed to give me a son, and deserves her exile. HENRY kisses ANNE) Which leaves you all alone at court.. ...queen in all but name. Mother to any future heir. So, is this assurance enough? Will you give yourself to me now?

question: I'd like to. But I'm afraid I find the insult too much to bear.
answer: What insult?

question: Because as long as we remain unmarried, any child I gave you would forever be daubed `bastard' and I a `whore'.
answer: ut what alternative is there? throws hands up in exasperation) My love for the Queen may have died, but even you must concede, she is still very much alive. A

question: Katherine of Aragon is alive. That woman is not worthy of the title `Queen'.
answer: Oh, Anne.

question: I really do not know why we waste time talking of convents when you could annul the marriage.
answer: Annul it?

question: That woman married two brothers and therefore sinned against God.
answer: But she never consummated the marriage with my brother.

question: They were married six months.
answer: Arthur was a sick man.

question: And Katherine is a shrewd woman who knew that her position as Queen would never be safe until she bedded your brother. Talk to your advisers. They will tell you as much.
answer: Wolsey has agreed to charge the Queen?

question: But that's wonderful. Why do you look sad?
answer: Because she will contest it. Which means putting her on trial. And hearing these delicate matters in public.

question: Thank you.
answer: I brought gifts from your family. A night-dress from your mother. This from your Uncle George.

question: Please be sure to thank them - though one wonders what's kept them so busy that not a single one of them found time to visit the new baby.
answer: It's Anne. She's turning this country on its head. She has persuaded the king to test the validity of his marriage, and put the QueenM on trial.

question: What?
answer: She continues to hold out. Expertly witholding her favours until...

question: ..until what?
answer: Until he makes her the ultimate offer.

question: High stakes indeed. And my brother George?
answer: ow is your husband? I heard he was unwell.

question: He is.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: The Queen has insisted a Papal representative be present at the trial. But Wolsey has assured me the trial will proceed for appearance sake only. We have our verdict.
answer: Then what troubles you?

question: One or two friends have refused to lend their support. Among them, Thomas More. And then there's the small matter of my conscience.
answer: Why? You have justice on your side.

question: `Mary Talbot'.
answer: Who?

question: Mary Talbot!! The girl that married Henry Percy. It seems she has petitioned the King, demanding a divorce from her husband ...that his prior betrothal to you was actually.. ..consummated. I knew this would come back to haunt us!
answer: I must go to the King.

question: No! He doesn't want to see you! Or hear a word from your lips! He's far too angry. a beat) It seems the only Boleyn he will speak to, the only person who's testimony he will trust in this matter.. ...is Mary.
answer: Mary?

question: Mary. We're so sorry. clears throat) About your husband..
answer: uch beautiful hair. Thank you for coming. I hate how this matter has come between us. I wanted to come to see you after your daughter was born, and again when your husband died, but..

question: ou asked to see me, your Grace?
answer: And..?

question: Nothing.
answer: I am forever in your debt.

question: You owe me nothing, sister. I did it that we may finally draw a line beneath everything that has happened between us.
answer: hen let it be exactly that. A new start between us. Here at court.

question: Thank you. But I'd rather go back to our home in the country.
answer: What? That damp old ruin? With no food? Or warmth? a beat) Why don't you let your family look after you? Your children would have the best of everything here. They would grow up safe and secure.

question: Wolsey promised the King his verdict. Instead he has humiliated him.
answer: But they are continuing with the trial. And the Bishops will still find in the King's favour.

question: Yes. But without the Pope's blessing, the result will seem hollow. a frustrated gesture) If only the King would take matters into his own hands.
answer: Nor his good sense. Breaking with Rome would isolate England politically. Leave us at the mercy of the Protestants.

question: Who's this?
answer: Go, on..

question: Is it, now? A fine name. And how old are you? I think so. Would you like to see it? Now, `on guard'. Now you will give yourself to me.
answer: I thought I had made myself clear. Until we are married, there is no questi..

question: Silence! Enough of your GAMES! I have torn apart this country for you, gone against every principle in my heart, I've endured the doubts and counsel of good men and silenced them with the axe...just to be with you.. Now prove to me it was worth the sacrifice.
answer: Stop, you are hurting me..! How was he with you? As a lover?

question: Did you hear? On the way to the church? They were calling me a witch.
answer: All that will die down as soon as they get to know you.

question: But what if it doesn't? What if they hate me forever?
answer: They won't. They will see how much the King loves you, and follow.

question: How much the King loves me?
answer: ister, I wonder if you've given any thought..to the matter of my returning to the country. With the children.

question: Wait! Mary.. I couldn't help overhearing. And before you agree to any of your sister's matches, let me just say.. ..I have saved money...not a lot...but enough. I've my eye on a place in the West...Tatton...near where I grew up..

question: Mary...I love you. There..I've said it. From the moment I joined your family..

question: Yes.
answer: Oh, Stafford..

question: Mary..I have watched how your family has treated you.
answer: But it's impossible. You know that. Now Anne's Queen, my family would never allow it.

question: But if it isn't? The King will take that as evidence of God's displeasure. And will turn further against me. He's already become so cold. They say you can tell by the shape of the stomach. Mary, what do you say? Boy or girl? What's the matter with her? You've been like this for days.
answer: What?

question: Mooning. You're not in love, are you?
answer: What? Certainly not.. In love! Well done...

question: And..?
answer: It's a girl! A beautiful, healthy girl.

question: The King will have to move swiftly to silence his enemies. He will claim innocence. That he was corrupted. Anne will swiftly be replaced as Queen, by someone more `acceptable'. And we Boleyns will never be able to show our faces at court again.
answer: That's no bad thing. Anyone with any sense would have run away from this hell-hole already. As far as they could go.

question: ike the wise William Stafford.

question: You didn't know? Sold up and went. Left for the country. Just like that. Gone to live in some place called..

question: I'm fine, thank you. Just a bad dream. But fetch my brother and sister, will you? I lost it. Almost without pain. And so fast it was over in a moment.

question: he King would never lie with me now, and risk damaging the `child' he believes I'm carrying.. a beat) Besides, he is barely capable anymore. And I couldn't go through that again. No, if I am to survive..I have to take matters into my own hands.

question: I need a baby, Mary. rolling eyes) Must I spell it out?

question: Stop it, Anne! It's madness..

question: I can't listen to this.. ...this is monstrous..

question: No, Anne! I understand you have had a shock tonight. A terrible shock. But there is no need for this.. Come, George..

question: No. Come, George..
answer: George, is STAYING!

question: I pray for you both.
answer: Mary! Come back!

question: Come on, darling wake up. Away from here. Far, far away. Someone. A friend. William? I'm sorry. a beat) I just didn't know where else to go. I do. What is it?

question: hat? It's Anne. Tell me.. She miscarried the child?
answer: They say it was deformed...monstrous. She is charged with incest and of summoning the devil. Your brother, too. He has already been sentenced. Anne is in the Tower, awaiting trial.

question: I must go.
answer: And do what? George is doomed. For Anne it's only a matter of time.

question: I can petition the King..
answer: ou think he will listen? It's his own neck he's saving by getting rid of them, can't you see? Fine, go. But if you do, you might as well kiss your children goodbye. You are Anne's sister. That alone makes you her accomplice and co-conspirator.

question: I have no choice. Anne and George are my family. I cannot desert them.
answer: And what of your new family? Your CHILDREN?

question: It is a sad day for England when the nobles do not rise for their Queen.
answer: And even sadder when that same Queen is charged with adultery and incest.

question: Charged is different to convicted, Uncle. Or is it not? In this court?
answer: Master Cromwell, read out the indictment.. How do you plead?

question: Not guilty, my Lord. My noble Lords..the love I have for my brother is the love any sister would have for someone with whom she has grown up in the same house, nursed when sick, played games as children, shared life's celebrations. That is the love I have for him. Not what you suggest.
answer: Guilty. In which case, the burden falls on me to pass sentence.

question: ALL of you!
answer: Your Majesty.. I understand my family has offended you. But having taken my brother today, I beg you to spare my sister.

question: Oh, Mary...
answer: I realise you must replace Anne as Queen. But must she die, too?

question: She has been tried and found guilty.
answer: You could send her away.

question: You could send her to a nunnery. No one would know.
answer: Anne? To a nunnery?

question: There is precedent, my Lord. Louis of France did it, too. When his wife could not conceive.
answer: The French Queen was a blameless woman. Your sister a witch.
